Rather frequently creationist will come here and say something along the lines of "If evolution is true, than how did life start?" And people here generally lay into them for linking the two. However, they aren't entirely to blame for making the connection. Check out this article from CNN:
 
 http://www.cnn.com/2005/TECH/science/08/15/harvard.evolution.ap/index.html
 
 Some Harvard researchers are getting a million dollars a year to study the question of how life started. Note that the article claims that this is a question about evolution, and no where uses the term abiogenesis. My local paper also ran a story about this, and also claimed that it was a question about evolution. I'd be curious to know if anyone can find an article about this that actually makes the distinction between evolution and abiogenesis.

Yes, but the point is that even if we don't know exactly how life arose, that doesn't cast doubt on evolutionary theory. The theories of evolution apply to populations of living organisms. However, that does not mean that evolutionary principles, learned from evolutionary biology, can't be applied in other fields, for example, self-replicating organic molecules.

Abiogenesis = evolution, but evolution does not equal abiogenesis
 
 Studing how life could have evolved out of self replicating molecules is part of evolution, its not required to explain all of it though but it is an area within it.
With so much happening in the first couple days some 6000 years ago, it's easy to lump things together.
aww a good school like that being corrupted. whats the world coming to?

aww a good school like that being corrupted. whats the world coming to?

 
 You really, really, really ought to start reading the acticles before posting comments.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Harvard to study "evolution"
